case_name: State of U.P. v. Col. Sujan Singh

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 23, 1962 of the Allahabad High Court Lucknow Bench at Lucknow in Criminal Revision No. 251 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 71 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 23, 1962 of the Allahabad High Court  Lucknow Be

facts.text: The respondents were prosecuted in the court of the Special Judge, Anti-Corruption East, U.P., Lucknow for an offence under s. 6(1)(a) of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 after obtaining sanction of the Central Government under s. 197 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents were prosecuted in the said Court, after obtaining the sanction of the Central Government under s. 197 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, for an offence under s. 6 1  a  of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947  Act 11 of 1947 .

facts.text: Objection taken by respondents that sanctioning authority did not apply mind properly when sanction granted.

anchor.surface_text: An objection was taken before the said court on behalf of the respondents that the sanctioning authority did not apply his mind properly when sanction for the prosecution was granted.

facts.text: Col. Sujan Singh, one of the accused, made a representation for reconsideration of prosecution order.

anchor.surface_text: It was stated on behalf of the respondents that on a representation made by one of the accused, Col. Sujan Singh, for reconsideration of the order of his prosecution,

facts.text: Deputy Secretary in Home Department reconsidered and made notings that earlier sanction given on insufficient data.

anchor.surface_text: the Deputy Secretary in the Home Department reconsidered the matter and made notings on his application to the effect that the sanction accorded earlier for his prosecution was given on insufficient data.

facts.text: Respondents filed petition before Special Judge to summon concerned record of Home Department.

anchor.surface_text: He filed a petition before the Special Judge to summon the concerned record of the Home Department on the ground that the said record would substantiate his assertion

facts.text: Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs claimed privilege on ground production not in interests of State.

anchor.surface_text: The Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs, claimed privilege on the ground that the production of the record containing the said notings of the Deputy Secretary would not be in the interests of the State.

facts.text: Special Judge rejected the claim of privilege.

anchor.surface_text: The Special Judge in the first instance and the High Court in revision rejected the claim of privilege raised by the Union Government.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court rejected privilege claim in revision.

anchor.surface_text: The Special Judge in the first instance and the High Court in revision rejected the claim of privilege raised by the Union Government.

facts.text: State of U.P. preferred present appeal by special leave against High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: The State of U.P. has preferred the present appeal by special leave against the order of the High Court.

facts.text: Certified copy of High Court judgment delivered to appellant on December 5, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: A certified copy of the Judgment was delivered to the appellant on December 5, 1962.

facts.text: Appellant filed petition in High Court for certificate on December 19, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: On December 19, 1962, the appellant filed a petition in the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad for a certificate

facts.text: High Court held on February 18, 1963 that order was interlocutory, petition not maintainable under Art. 134(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: On February 18, 1963, the High Court held that the order sought to be appealed against was an interlocutory one and, therefore, the petition was not maintainable under Art. 134 1  c  of the Constitution of India.

facts.text: Appellant filed petition for special leave in Supreme Court on April 16, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: On April 16, 1963 the appellant filed a petition in this Court for special leave to appeal against the order of the High Court in the criminal revision.

facts.text: Special leave granted on May 10, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant contends that special leave was -ranted on May 10, 1963,

facts.text: Respondents 1 and 2 received notice granting special leave on January 16, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Respondents 1 and 2 received the notice granting special leave by this Court on January 16, 1964.

facts.text: Notice of dispatch of records served on counsel for respondents on November 4, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: But the notice of the dispatch of the records was served on the learned counsel for respondents 1 and 2 on November 4, 1963.

facts.text: Respondents filed appearance on February 11, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: On February 11, 1964, they filed their appearance and on February 18, 1964, their statement of case.

facts.text: Court excused delay in respondents' appearance and statement of case.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we think that this is a fit case for excusing the delay. We excuse the delay in filing respondents appearance and also in lodging the statement of case.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed as barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: So. the appeal is clearly barred by limitation and should be dismissed. Accordingly the appeal is dismissed.

facts.text: High Court order of February 18, 1963 refusing certificate became final, no appeal filed against it.

anchor.surface_text: That apart the order of the High Court holding that the order sought to be appealed from was not a final order within the meaning of Art. 134 1  of the Constitution has become final. The appellant has not filed any appeal against that order.

facts.text: Government decided to file appeal on March 8, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: From the information supplied by the counsel for the appellant it appears that the Government decided to file the appeal only on March 8, 1963, i.e., after the time for filing the appeal had expired.

facts.text: Special leave petition was out of time by 42 days if certificate application not maintainable.

anchor.surface_text: for in the latter event the time would have expired on March 5, 1963, and the appeal would have been out of time by 42 days.

facts.text: Law Officer advised that order was final and application under Art. 134(1)(c) should be filed first.

anchor.surface_text: the Law Officer, who was at the relevant time in charge of the matter in the High Court, advised the Government that the order under appeal was a final order and that an application should be filed under Art. 134 1  c  of the Constitution

facts.text: Raghubar Dayal J. delivered dissenting opinion.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of SUBBA RAO and DA, GUPTA JJ. was delivered by SUBBA RAO J. RAGHUBAR DAYAL J. delivered a dissenting Opinion.

holdings.text: We, therefore, hold that the order made by the High Court is not a final order within the meaning of Art. 134(1) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the order made by the High Court is not a final order within the meaning of Art. 134 1  of the Constitution. That apart the order of the High Court holding that the order sought to be appealed from was not a final order within the meaning of Art. 134 1  of the Constitution has become final.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order merely interlocutory procedural step for summoning documents, does not bind or affect parties' rights of its own force; follows Seth Premchand Satramdas definition of final order.

holdings.text: the period of limitation for filing the special leave petition could not be computed from the date of the order of the High Court refusing to give a certificate to appeal to the Supreme Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Certificate application not maintainable as order interlocutory; O.XXI r.1 SC Rules presupposes maintainable application; refusal order final and unchallenged.

holdings.text: we do not see any justification for excusing the long delay of 42 days.

anchor.surface_text: On the said facts we do not see any justification for excusing the long delay of 42 days. So. the appeal is clearly barred by limitation and should be dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Wrong legal advice insufficient ground; no action after HC held application unmaintainable on Feb 18, 1963; govt decided to appeal only on March 8, 1963 post-limitation expiry.

holdings.text: the appeal is clearly barred by limitation and should be dismissed. Accordingly the appeal is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: So. the appeal is clearly barred by limitation and should be dismissed. Accordingly the appeal is dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Special leave petition filed 42 days late from March 5, 1963; delay not condoned; non-compliance with O.XXI r.2 SC Rules by not disclosing certificate refusal grounds.

holdings.text: In accordance with the opinion of the majority, the delay in filing the special leave petition is not condoned.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Final order implementing majority view dismissing appeal on limitation.

anchor.surface_text: Seth Premchand Satramdas v. The State of Bihar 1  it was held that an order of the Patna High Court dismissing an application under s. 21 3  of the Bihar Sales Tax Act, 1944, to direct the Board of Revenue, Bihar, to state a case and to refer it to the 1950 S.C.R. 799,, 804.

precedents.case_name: Seth Premchand Satramdas v. The State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: An order cannot be regarded as a final order because it does not of its own force bind or affect the rights of the parties
precedents.cited_holding: It seems to us that the order appealed against in this case cannot be regarded as a final order, because it does not of its own force bind or affect the rights of the parties.
